I always consider her as a great character. Some time around playing Episode Two, she became best fictious character ever for me. But that has changed after tenth anniversary of Episode Two. When it was one decade, it hit me. These were extraordinary times. I was reading Epistle 3, listened Path of Borealis over and over, and was very depressed because for both of story and real world were futile hope. When I was playing Half-Life 2 series these days (which was my best playthrough), I realized it. I love Half-Life universe and more of that, I really love Alyx Vance.

I love her as a person. And everything on her. Her name, her appearance with brown jacket patched by duct tape, her Merle Dandridge's voice, her personality, being badass, being frightened, style of speech, movements, silly attempts to be funny. Et cetera.

There is vast amount of characters in many media that are more elaborated. Alyx isn't extra particularly shown. No it's not a question of occurrence. It's a concept of human. And that's absolutely genius. She has it inside.

I thought that because she is fictious, and there won't be more official content, she will remain forever, who she is. Woman in her mid-twenties, with headband and unmistakable hairstyle. She will never change and she will never die.

I feel sorry for her, whenever I see any ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• about her. She doesn't deserve that.

This is also extraordinary day. Last day, when Alyx is still known only from Half-Life 2 series. But old perception of Alyx is gone already and new has not yet been created. I am mad becuase there will be Half-Life with her name in the title. This is something I always imagined, but I was always scared how Valve could handle it.

Tomorrow we will see new side of Alyx. My love to her isn't gonna be changed by that or anything. I'm a completely hopeless case.

In comparison to its predecessor, Half Life 2 is an extraordinary game, but even on its own it is still an incredible experience. I had several gripes with the first installment, but this game has done away with them all. The source engine is a beautiful piece of technology that has put its mark on the gaming industry, and, back in the day, must have been a revolutionary development. I don't think Half-Life 2 would be the same without it.

That said, the game is very good. The gameplay is beyond solid, there's a good storyline to follow (with the exception that you receive little to no backstory on the entire ordeal), there are a few protagonist NPC's (all of whom have their own distinct and noticeable personality that you can love or hate), and the audio is good (though the amount of helicopter noise often drowns out other stuff).

Perhaps the one gripe i have with the series as a whole, is that very little is explained. Half Life 1 left me with many questions, and rather than getting answers, Half Life 2 has added many new uncertainties to the list. If there was ever to come a Half Life 3, it'd better have some knowledge bombs.

Either way, the game is recommended to everyone, especially since you can pick it up for around a buck or two during the sales.

One of the best games of all time. Its so weird to me that this game was released in 2004. It must have been revolutionary for that time, and to this day it still doesnt feel that old.

The game has an amazing storyline, character development, creepy atmosphere that is consistant throughout the whole game, lots of different puzzles using objects with your gravity gun, intense fights, variety of weapons etc.

Without a doubt 100% worth buying. Every gamer should experience this.
